Munute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Appearing for the Government, Alberto Lopez, for deft., Juan J. Hernandez and PO Tania Correa. Arraignment/Detention as to Jazmin Velazquez-Pica (8) as to Count 1,2- 4,5 held on 10/6/2011. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. Case is referred to Judge Garcia-Gregory for trial setting. As to Detention, defense counsel argued in favor of bail. The Government had no objection to the recommendation made by the pretrial officer and requested home detention and EMD. The Court adopted all recommendations made by pretrial and imposed bail in the amount of $10,000.00 of which $2,000.00 are to be cash or secured and $8,000.00 unsecured, non electronic curfew from 6:00 pm until 6:00 am, defendant  cannot be released until a land line is installed at the residence, drug test, substance abuse treatment, defendant shall not reside, go in or near Brisas Del Mar Public Housing, plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter F.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 01:46.Hearing ended at 01:55.Interpreter Hilda Gutierrez. (ft) (Entered: 10/13/2011)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive: Arraignment/Bail Hearings as to Roberto Martinez-Martinez (22) Count 1,2-4,5 held on 12/21/2011. AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Alex O. Rosa were present. AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Laura Maldonado were present. The Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. As to Bail, defense counsel had no evidence to rebut the government's presumption, but will reserve the right to reopen the matter of bail. Having no evidence presented by defense, the Court will follow the recommendation made by Pretrial to detain defendant without bail. The Court noted that defendant is reserving the right to reopen the hearing if bail is made available. (Court Reporter FTR/bg, CD: Brenda Gonzalez, PO: Tania Correa.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:53. Hearing ended at 02:55. Interpreter Enith Valdes. (br) (Entered: 12/23/2011)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Motion Hearing as to Arturo Alejandro-Martinez held on 5/29/2012, re: 545 INFORMATIVE Motion MOTION for Hearing filed by Arturo Alejandro-Martinez. AUSA Alberto Lopez, defense counsel Luis R. Rivera and Lydia Lizarribar were present. Oral arguments as to various subjects were heard extensively by defendant. The Court denied defendant's request to reopen the matter of bail. Defendant informed that he will remain with both retained counsel. Counsel Lizarribar informed that all Cds provided by the Government in the discovery package have been reviewed except for two that may be defective. The Government will be providing the new Cds by the end of business today. The Government is willing to extend the plea offer again. The Court advised defendant that he may renegotiate the plea agreement but not the charging documents. The Court advised defendant that, if he does not decide to plea, the trial will remain as scheduled providing both parties ten (10) days to prepare for trial. Change of Plea Hearing set for 6/8/2012 10:30 AM in Courtroom 8 before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll. (Deft. Exhs Adm.: 1 thru 8 were returned to defendant at the end of the hearing). (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 01:30. Hearing held at 02:16. Hearing ended at 03:14. (br) (Entered: 06/01/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Arturo Alejandro-Martinez held on 6/8/2012. AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Lydia Lizarribar were present. Defense counsel informed that her client will not be willing to plea and wish to be heard. Defendant addressed the Court. Counsel informed that the Cds were received, but unable to heard by defendant, since he was ill. The Government was heard in argument and informed that all discovery was provided on time. Counsel Lizarribar informed that when she was retained, defendant informed of not seeing the Cds and evidence. The parties were granted time to meet and discuss whether defendant will plea or not, since the plea offer is due today. After a recess, defendant wish to plea. Consent was approved, filed and made part of the record. The defendant was found competent to plea. The Magistrate Judge will recommend to the Court that the Plea of Guilty be accepted as to Count One (1) of the Indictment. At the time of sentencing, the Government will request the dismissal of the remaining counts. The defendant is to remain under custody. The Court ordered the preparation of a presentence report. Sentence will be set at a later date. A report and recommendation will be issued. s/c: PO through e-mail. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 10:30. Hearing held at 10:59. Hearing ended at 12:56. Interpreter N/A. (br) (Entered: 06/12/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Eric Texidor-Rosario (27) held on 4/19/2016. Present were AUSA Dina Avila for Maria Montanez, and AFPD Jesus Hernandez. Defendant was present O/B and assisted by the court interpreter. The Court described the background of the case and the decision not to revoke at this time. Instead the Court added a new condition of release as follows: "The defendant shall participate in an approved mental health treatment program for evaluation and/or treatment services determination. If deemed necessary, the treatment will be arranged by the officer in consultation with the treatment provider; the modality, duration and intensity of the treatment will be based on the risks and needs identified. The defendant will contribute to the costs of services rendered by means of co-payment, based on his ability to pay or a third party payment. Treatment will be focused in anger management." Defendant was admonished and ordered to fully comply with the supervised release conditions. Any violations to his supervised release will result in revocation and imposition of an imprisonment term. The remaining conditions imposed in sentencing remain the same. As to defendant's request to travel, defendant shall meet with the US Probation Officer and the officer shall inform the Court if defendant is ready to travel and any other recommendation to the Court. (Court Reporter Evilys Carrion.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 09:43.Hearing ended at 09:47. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (al) (Entered: 04/20/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Re-sentencing as to Jose Colon-Romero (18) held on 6/23/2017. AUSA Marc Chattah and defense counsel Juan Albino were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defense counsel was heard and requested time served. The government had no objection to time served. No allocution was heard by defendant. On 8/10/2012, the defendant was sentenced to 63 months of imprisonment with a supervised release term of eight (8) years, and a special monetary assessment $100. On 10/26/2015, the defendant benefitted from USSG 782 Amendment and was sentenced to a 60 months imprisonment term. On 5/23/2017, defense counsel filed a motion seeking concurrency with the defendant's state sentencing imposed on 6/9/2011, in criminal cases numbered DSC2011G0089 and DSC2011G0090, under the basis of relevant conduct, pursuant to Rule 6(a) of the Federal Criminal Procedure. On 6/6/2017, the United States stated its position as ordered by the Court while considering the above- referenced cases relevant conduct in the charged conspiracy. The Court imposed sentenced as follows: IMPR: 60 month (time already served) to be served concurrent with the state court sentence in Cases DSC2011G0089 and DSC2011G0090. SRT: 8 years. SMA: $100.00. The defendant is advised of his right to appeal, etc. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. (Court Reporter Lisa O'Brien.) Hearing set for 03:00. Hearing held at 04:02. Hearing ended at 04:10. Interpreter Edna Brayfield. (br) (Entered: 06/26/2017)

AMENDED JUDGMENT as to Jose Colon-Romero (18): Count(s) 1, 60 month (time already served) to be served concurrent with the state court sentence in Cases DSC2011G0089 and DSC2011G0090. SRT: 8 years. SMA: $100.00. Count(s) 2-4, 5, Dismissed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/23/2017.(br) (Entered: 06/26/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Preliminary Revocation and Detention Hearing as to Anthony J. Colon-Maldonado (24) held on 9/11/2017. Present: AUSA Maria Montanez, AFPD Andrew McCutcheon, USPO Nelson Mendoza. Defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Testimony of USPO Nelson Mendoza was heard on behalf of the government. Cross-examination conducted. Government Exhibit 1 admitted. After hearing the testimony of the witness, the Court found probable cause as to the first allegation contained in the motion filed by Probation - "The defendant shall not commit another federal, state or local crime" and referred the matter to Judge Francisco A.  Besosa for final revocation hearing. As to the second violation, "The defendant shall answer truthfully all inquiries by the probation officer and follow the instructions of the probation", no probable cause was found. Government requested detention pending final revocation hearing. Defense counsel argued for bail. The Court granted government's motion and ordered defendant detained. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Joaquin Nieves-Colon (20) held on 12/15/2017. Present were AUSA Kelly Zenon and AFPD Samantha Drake. Defendant was present and under custody. Waiver of preliminary hearing filed and approved. Probable cause found as to the motion filed by Probation under docket 1169. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for the full hearing. As to bail, AFPD Drake argued for bail, explaining the situation which allegedly caused his abandoning the inpatient program where he was at. The Government vehemently opposed bail. After hearing the arguments from the parties, and conferring with them at sidebar together with USPO Yvette Villegas, the Court denied bail and ordered defendant detained pending the final hearing. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 10:38.Hearing ended at 10:46.Interpreter -Carlos Lao. (yr) (Entered: 12/18/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Joaquin Nieves-Colon (20) held on 1/29/2018. AUSA Kelly Zenon, AFPD Samantha Drake and USPO Ivette Villegas were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant allocution heard. After having heard the parties, the Court finds that defendant violated the conditions of the imposed supervised release term. Therefore, the terms of supervised release imposed in this case was revoked. It is the judgment of the Court, that defendant is hereby committed to the custody of the US BOP for a term of 3 months and SRT of 6 years. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Joaquin Nieves-Colon (20) held on 2/20/2019. Present were AUSA Max Perez and AFPD Ivan Santos. Defendant was present and under custody. Waiver of preliminary hearing filed and approved. Probable cause found as to docket 1270, and the case was referred to Judge Garcia for the final revocation hearing. AFPD Santos requested that defendant remained under the same conditions of supervised release until the final revocation hearing in order to receive the substance abuse treatment he needs and is willing to take. The Government opposed his release, although recognizing that defendant does have an addiction for which he needs treatment. After hearing all the arguments from the parties, the Court ruled that defendant will remain under custody. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:01.Hearing ended at 10:11.Interpreter -Felix Toledo. (yr) (Entered: 03/04/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Joaquin Nieves-Colon (20) held on 3/19/2019. Present were AUSA Maria Montanez, AFPD Edwin Mora and USPO Ivette Villega. The Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant accepted the allegations. Defendants allocution heard. After hearing the parties. This Court will not revoke his term of supervised release at this time and the conditions of supervision ordered during sentencing on September 5, 2018, remain in effect. Parties agreed that Defendant will be staying with his sister from today until Friday March 22, 2019. On Friday he will be entering Guarabi for drug treatment. However, the condition of electronic monitoring for a period of 6 months will be imposed additionally, after you complete the period in the residential substance abuse program. ORDER re 1376 Motion in Compliance as to Anthony J. Colon-Maldonado (24): GRANTED. Pursuant to the Court of Appeals, this case was remanded for a re- sentencing of the revocation on appeal. However, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and pursuant to the Order issued by Chief Judge Gelpi under the CARES Act (20-mc-0088), the Court finds that this re-sentencing hearing cannot be conducted in person in this district without seriously jeopardizing public health and safety, and that this case cannot be further delayed without serious harm to the interest of justice. Defendant's waiver of a final revocation hearing is accepted. The Court has taken into consideration the recommendation of the probation officer (Docket No. 1374 ) and the government's position (Docket No. 1375 ). Accordingly, defendant is re-sentenced to a term of IMPR.: Time served; No additional supervision to follow. Amended Judgment on Revocation will be issued. Signed by Judge Francisco A. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Joel Reyes-Marquez (2) held on 12/17/2020 via VTC. The defendant was present and assisted by a certified court interpreter. AFPD Edwin Mora was also present. The defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed by way of VTC. The defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motion filed at Docket No. 1388 and as to his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether the supervised release conditions had been violated. Upon the defendant's request, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by the FPD's Office. As required by Rule 5(f), the United States is ordered to produce all exculpatory evidence to the defendant pursuant to Brady v. Maryland and its progeny. Not doing so in a timely manner may result in sanctions, including exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges and contempt proceedings. Preliminary Revocation Hearing is set for 12/30/2020 at 10:00 AM in VTC Bridge BJM before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin. The defendant is ordered temporarily detained. (Court Reporter Zulma Ruiz.) Hearing held at 11:15. Hearing ended at 11:19. Interpreter Ani Navarro. (bgl) (Entered: 12/18/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Francisco A. Besosa:Case called for Revocation on Supervised Release as to Joel Reyes-Marquez (2) held on 2/10/2021. Present via VTC AUSA Richard Vance Eaton, and AFPD Andrew McCutcheon. USPO Carolina Aparicio also present. The defendant was under custody at MDC-Guaynabo and was assisted by certified court interpreter Sonia Crescioni. All parties connected remotely. The record should reflect the proceedings are being held by VTC, given the emergency situation created by the COVID-19 pandemic. The defendant during today's hearing waived his right to be physically present for the revocation hearing and consented to proceed by VTC as filed at ECF No. 1405. The Court made a finding that the defendant knowingly and voluntarily waived the right to be physically present for today's proceedings, since the defendant has consented to proceed by videoconference after consultation with his counsel of record. Certified court interpreter Sonia Crescioni was acting and assisting the defendant on a secured line at MDC-Guaynabo and the Court had a clear view of him on screen. AFPD McCutcheon proceeded to provide several mitigation factors to be considered by the Court and requested the defendant be sentenced to time served, and be allowed to travel to New York to face the charges pending against him there. The United States had no objection. The Court after hearing the parties determined not to revoke defendant Reyes-Marquez (2) but will remain under the same supervised conditions previously imposed. The Court ordered that Defendant Reyes-Marquez (2) shall be released forthwith. Upon release from MDC- Guaynabo, defendant Reyes-Marquez (2) shall report to the U.S. Probation Office. Specific instructions were given by USPO Aparicio. Then defendant will be allowed to travel to New York to face the pending charges against him. If he is convicted, he should inform the U.S. Probation Office for him to face potential revocation proceedings in this case. (Court Reporter Joe Reynosa.)Hearing set for 10:00.Hearing held at 10:05.Hearing ended at 10:26.Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. USPO Carolina Aparicio (om) (Entered: 02/10/2021)

ORDER re 1418 Motion for Early Termination of Probation/SRT as to Juan Frias- Rivera (4). The probation officer will confirm that she does not object to defendant Frias-Rivera's termination of his supervised release term, and will provide the Court with a more detailed motion, showing all "special, extraordinary or unforeseen circumstances that warrant termination” of defendant's supervised release term. Early termination is not warranted when a defendant does nothing more than that which he was required to do by law. Whittingham v. U.S., No. 14-cv-7738 (RJS), 2017 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77454 (S.D.N.Y. ORDER re 1428 Motion for Early Termination of Probation as to Roberto Rivera- Mendez (23): DENIED. Although the probation officer has indicated that defendant Rivera-Mendez has satisfied all the conditions imposed on him during his supervised release term, that is not enough. "Early termination is not warranted where a defendant did nothing more than that which he was required to do by law." Whittingham v. United States, 2017 U.S. Dist., LEXIS 77454 at *18 (S.D.N.Y.
